The Future of PMM

Issue #3 February 28, 2026
Welcome to Week 3

This week we focus on the agentic shift ‚Äî and what it means when your buyer stops being a person and starts being an algorithm.

I've been thinking about this for months, but this week I finally wrote it down: the uncomfortable truth that everything we assume about product marketing ‚Äî personas, messaging hierarchies, content-to-conversion pipelines ‚Äî breaks when an AI agent is doing the evaluation.

We also spotlight someone who's already building for this future: Hyunsoo "Soo" Shim, whose BattleCoach prototype shows what competitive intelligence looks like when it's designed for scale.

Let's get into it. ‚ÄîChris

üìñ This Week's Essay
üöÄ Agentic PMM Series ‚Äî Part 1

Your Buyer Just Hired an Agent. Now What?

Here's the uncomfortable truth most product marketers haven't internalized yet: your buyer is disappearing. Not literally ‚Äî but increasingly, humans are deploying agents to do the work that used to land them on your website.

This essay digs into:

  • Why the old frameworks are broken ‚Äî personas, SEO, content marketing all assumed human discovery patterns
  • The K-shaped future ‚Äî the widening gap between AI-native PMMs and everyone else
  • Discoverability as the new battleground ‚Äî what happens when agents don't use Google
  • MCP vs. end-to-end activation ‚Äî two strategic paths forward
Read the full essay ‚Üí
üèÜ User of the Week
‚≠ê User of the Week

Hyunsoo "Soo" Shim ‚Äî Building an AI Sales Simulator That Thinks Like a PMM

While most PMMs are using AI to write emails faster, Soo is building BattleCoach ‚Äî an agentic AI prototype that transforms static competitive content into dynamic coaching for sellers.

The insight that sparked it: "Our competitive messaging often fails the logo swap test." If you can swap your logo for a competitor's and the messaging still works, you don't have differentiation.

Her approach: a 3-day workshop to create 9 solution-level playbooks (3 buying scenarios √ó 3 competitors), then encode that intelligence into an AI system that can scale.

Crawl ‚Üí Walk ‚Üí Run:

  • Crawl: Structured competitive intelligence framework
  • Walk: Context-aware AI co-pilot
  • Run: Autonomous competitive coaching
Read the full profile ‚Üí
üì∞ News Roundup

1OpenAI Turns ChatGPT Into an Ad Platform

800 million users just became the product. OpenAI's February announcement validated what many predicted: every AI assistant builder is now an ad company. Your brand's presence in AI-mediated conversations just became a paid media question.

2Salesforce Spring 2026: AI Agents Across CRM

Salesforce expanded Agentforce with new autonomous agents for marketing, sales, and service. The agents can now handle multi-step workflows without human intervention. The race to embed agentic capabilities into enterprise software is officially on.

3Oracle Launches Role-Based AI Agents

Oracle is betting that role-based agents ‚Äî not standalone tools ‚Äî will let revenue teams cut through data silos. New agents for marketers, sellers, and CS teams can pull context from across Fusion applications.

4Google Announces AI Mode Checkout Protocols

Google introduced standards allowing AI agents to complete purchases directly within its ecosystem. Translation: buyer agents can now transact without human involvement. If your checkout flow isn't agent-friendly, you're invisible.

5B2BMX 2026: The "Infinite Content Graveyard"

The Demand Gen Report's conference preview says it plainly: "AI-powered is no longer a differentiator‚Äîit's the baseline." Every whitepaper sounds the same. Every LinkedIn outreach feels like a robot talking to a robot. The new question: what actually breaks through?

That's a Wrap

The agentic shift is real, and it's happening faster than most marketing orgs realize. The question isn't whether AI will change product marketing ‚Äî it's whether you'll be the one shaping that change or reacting to it.

See you next Friday.
